description: I lived above this bar for 4 years. Sure it's a dive but I've had many of the best nights of my life here. The bartenders are wonderful people if you get to know them and the drinks are strong. You can get a red horse beer 8% abv for $5. Jukebox, pool table, 2 TV's, what more could you want. I called this place home for a long time and every time I visit town I walk into the bar unannounced and whoever is working behind the bar that night will see me, freak out, and run around the bar to give me a big hug. This place is home, I even have a tattoo of the "high tides waves" on my leg for all the unforgettable nights I've had here.
author: Dave S.

description: Celebrating my friend's acceptance to medical school a group of ten of us descended unto this dive bar Saturday around 7pm. Despite probably coming off as a bit of a nuisance we were warmly welcomed and they even didn't mind us moving some tables so that we could all sit together. We ended up ordering 4 pitchers (a bit on the expensive side for what it was) and borrowed some dice to play games. The vibes were super chill (relative to the generally uppity nature of downtown bars) and we really enjoyed being here. A couple small  down sides were the cash only policy as well as the the slightly wonky music selection; this place definitely caters to an older crowd. They also only had one pitcher available and we were made to pay for each one as we got it which was just a bit odd. Overall, though, I'd definitely come back if I was just looking for a quick drink.
author: Andrew P.

description: This is the best bar in San Fran in my opinion. The bartenders are all great the drinks are cheap and good. This is the place that I miss that most about San Fran. Defiantly recommend this place you will not regret it and you might even have a new favorite bar
author: Daequan J.

description:
Stopped by for a quick drink while waiting for some pizzas we ordered down the street. This was on Friday, September 16th around 8:30pm.

It wasn't very busy, so our group of three just snagged a table against the wall. I got a Bulleit on the rocks. One of my friends got a Jameson and ginger. The other, a Jameson and soda. The bar is divey, but the bartender was super nice and chill. We got our drinks quickly. The decor is fun and eclectic. I believe they had actual dollar bills plastered all over the walls. I noticed some foreign currency as well. Not sure what you need to do to get a bill posted, but I kind of remember there being messages written on them. So maybe you just need to tip the bartender and write a note on your bill?

Convenient for a round of drinks. I wouldn't call this a destination type of bar, but if you're nearby, High Tide could be a good, quick, pit stop.
author: Elena N.

description: They only accept cash and the bar is super dirty, the bartender she was extremely rude and the prices is crazy for a disgusting water down drinks. Never again.
author: Rahab A.

description: This place is a guilty pleasure. Cheep beer, pool table and a juke box. The night can be a lot of fun based on which bartenders are working. We've been here on a quieter night and had the jukebox turned off so the bartender could watch the Miss Universe pageant but other times the bartenders have been on the other side of the bar dancing with us.
author: Sarah S.

description: Great place great service for Asian .. good whisky good beer. Servers from Korea look like 25's great service .. good price for any drinks
author: Sy F.

description: Pretty cool spot.  Music hella loud.  Raider game on.  Drinks strong.  Bart tender fierce to throw out some homeless guy and a meth-head.
author: MImi M.

description:
Tiny drinks, huge price tags. Also, it's cash only.

The prices are typical, but the portions are very, very small. I wish I had taken pictures of the drinks I had two weekends ago. I ordered an amaretto sour, and it was made in a watered down shot glass. I kid you not. It was tiny!!!!! Delicious, but tiny! I was practically drinking juice out of a shot glass with a straw. My friend received what looked like the tiniest martini ever. If the drinks are so small and watered down, they can have the decency to lower the prices.

The only reason they have 2 stars instead of one is because of the fact that they were delicious and the atmosphere was quiet enough to rest after bar hopping. The music on the jukebox was good. The decor is also fun and interesting.
author: Brenda Y.

description:
I knew that someday I would happen upon a truly shitty dive bar during my downtown drinking adventures. And that bar is the High Tide. Usually I can find a lot of intrinsic charm and personality in these old watering holes. Not here.

Let's just list out the negatives that encapsulated my experience. They are cash only. I ordered a gin and tonic but they were "out of tonic" with no apparent urgency to get more. Our watered down, cheap drinks were 8 dollars each. The two ladies behind the bar seemed to have little idea what they were doing. Blaring Mexican ranchero music. An interior decor that doesn't make much sense. Sticky seats. 

Sometimes one or two of these quirks can make a dive more appealing. It's all a mess here.
author: Alex L.

description:
True dive bar
Cash only
Good for shots/beer
One pool table
Affordable

Overall Thoughts

Solid place to start or end the night
author: Eddie W.

description:
I love this place. A lot of time when people wanna meet me kinda near union square or anytime i have extra time before meeting people, High Tide is my go to. I just like the laid back divey vibe in here. The decor is everything to me. There is just this portrait of a beautiful topless woman at the center of the bar (it's wayyy classier than it sounds), and then there's cash taped to the walls everywhere. Exactly how i'd decorate my own dive bar! 
The place is pretty cold so everyone is always wearing a jacket. There's seats available at the bar, but also a few tables that are good for groups. There's a pool table in the other room but i've never played. Happy to just be sitting at the bar. The music is a bit on the loud side to have a normal conversation but what's a bar without loud music? If you expect a dive bar, this place is for you. As far as I've ever seen, they don't have like a cocktail menu or anything else. What you see is what you get.
author: Veronica L.

description: This place is the definition of a dive bar: dirty, sketchy, and one dollar bills, graffiti, and a framed photos of topless women serve as the decor. I can't speak on the quality of the mixed drinks, but I was very excited to get Arrogant Bastard on tap for $5.00. I docked a star because this place is cash only (!!!) and because I made it out without getting into a fist fight. Bonus points for the music selection which included Elvis Presley.
author: Javier M.

description:
Situation
- A friend of mine wanted to go here for his birthday (after a few bars)

Pros
- They serve beer and alcohol 
- High prices considering it's a lower end bar

Cons
- The bartenders added the shots they took to our order
- The place is just okay
author: Dipesh G.

description:
Now, if you're going to come here, you have to be a little like Adam S. and appreciate the art of the dive-bar.  Why are dive-bars great?  ...well, they're not.  Why are they good?  ...  You can come in, pretension-free, grab some drinks and relax.  This is an adequate, if average at best, spot.

Things you want in a dive-bar:  Cheap drinks.  Not here.  Entertaining bartenders who bring a lot of local color to the table.  Ehhh....  Some sort of amusing, although harmless drama.  Haven't seen it.  Good sight-lines to the TV's to catch a game.  Not so much.

Things you don't want in a dive-bar:   Murder.  No murder here.  Crazy (not in the good way) people.  It's been a pretty good crowd.  Indifferent service.  Actually, they do fine, although it's nothing special.

So perfectly adequate, but nothing special.  The one thing, to me, that elevates this from 2-stars to 3-stars is that it has a kind of kitschy, old-school decor that endears itself.  There is also a cool tradition of tricking-out your dollar bill and stapling it to the ceiling.  Check out the pics.  (I'm convinced that these end up in someone's pocket eventually, since I haven't found a couple of my dollars from past trips.)

It's worth a try.  It's also not a bad spot if you are returning from the Union Square area and want to catch a drink or use the bathroom on the way over to Polk Street.
author: Adam S.

description: totally a place where you bring a booty call or better yet a one night stand. The drinks are weak as fuck; you can really tell they water down the liquor. With a little coaching the bartender (at least she is willing to try) can make a somewhat decent drink; it'll taste like cool aid but its better than the usual concoctions. Also be very direct when ordering i.e. if you want rum and ginger beer say that, don't ask for a dark and stormy. Plus is the super cheap drinks everything, even mixed drinks are like $6 or $8. Sorta a fun place too if you like talking to drunk crazies. Thumbs up for a sold TL experience.
author: Sabrina D.

description:
Typical dive bar. 
Cocktails were a little pricey, in my opinion, and the pours not too impressive. Crowd seemed to be mostly locals and didn't seem very welcoming to outsiders. I felt a bit out of place there at the bar, so we retreated to one of the rear rooms where a pool table was. The place was a little dirty, but not out of the norm for a dive. Just didn't fit in with the vibe. After one drink we left. Female bartender was nice, though.
author: Gary R.

description:
The High Tide is a dive bar in the true sense. I can't decide how I feel about this little joint. But time tells me that I keep coming back here, year after year. What's the draw? Is it the filthy bathrooms? The overpriced booze? The mish-mash decor? The oddest selection of music ever compiled in a playlist? It must be a mix of those things, plus the bartenders, who don't seem to fit in to this joint. At all. 

I guess it shouldn't come as a surprise to me that everyone I bring to this bar enjoys it a lot. I mean, you can sort of just do whatever you want here. It's a place that, for those of us who constantly have to be "on" can just turn off and enjoy ourselves. 

And maybe, just maybe, this place makes me miss Carl at the Ha Ra just a little bit more every time.
author: Don B.

description:
I always struggle to rate dive bars - it's like, I had a ton of fun here, and I would totally come back next time I'm in SF (mostly to see if the Happy New Year banner is still up), but it's still a dive bar!

High Tide made me a little nostalgic for English pubs, in the sense that I wouldn't have been surprised to see a number of 60+ men glued to their barstools and scowling at the "youths." ...I guess this makes most English pubs dive bars *revelation!*

From the topless art behind the counter, to the countless $1 bills plastered to the ceiling, to the bizarre mish mash of cooking equipment behind the bar, this place was a weird treat. The friendly and sassy bartender was an added bonus you don't always get in dive bars. They also actually have a very respectable selection of booze, surprisingly!

A fun and quirky place to spend a little time, just probably not a whole evening!
author: Ayla C.

description: This place my shit. Low key. Divey. Friendly. They have tv's for games and all around tasty beverages. I'm a cocktail guy so not sure about beer sorry. Bottoms up!!!
author: S. L.

description: I really like this pub, usually it's slow and peaceful. Prices: beers 5$, gyntonic 8$. There is pool -1$ game.
author: Serg V.

description: I'm scuba Steven when it comes to Diver bar cruising....And this is establishment is very well equipped to give you what you need. Good poors of Barton gin and Thai bartenders that you can barely understand..... Money speaks all languages....Take care of them and they will take care of you :) Ling Ling My Friend Friend....
author: Joey F.

description:
What an unprofessional bar this was. It was weird since I read the good reviews, but maybe this bartender was new or had a bad day.

Right when we got there, our table ordered drinks.  Only but about 10 minutes later the bartender started yelling at the whole table behind the counter, that this isn't a restaurant and we need to buy more drinks now.  Some of the people in the group were driving and weren't drinking.  The bar was empty anyways and only had about 3 people sitting at the main counter, which it seemed like she was trying to impress and make laugh.  She was also ordering the table around and constantly yelling out random things.  It seemed like she was drunk on the job, but still this was unacceptable behavior.  If you're going to be drunk on the job, hold it together.  When we finally got up to leave because the girls got fed up with her, she yelled even more and commanded us to come back and order drinks.   

We originally went here for the pool table.  Instead of this bar, go to the Wreck Room for games and a much more chill environment, where bartenders don't go crazy and yell at you.
author: Eric T.

description:
Coming back to the city after a wedding weekend event in Napa and this is exactly the spot a few of the East Coast friends and I needed. Decent beers on tap for a reasonable price, a jukebox that offered comfortable tunes that allowed for conversations, and a small crowd that was friendly enough to join in on a joke but also bow out appropriately. Of course, it was a Sunday night, but the small TVs that offered a baseball game and football game were a good touch. 

Cash only! 

This is definitely a good choice to kick it at if you are around the area and looking for a relaxes dive bar scene.
author: Ryan Q.

description:
This is a great dive bar with a great jukebox. There is nothing fancy or pretentious about this place and that's what's part of its charm.
The bartenders are very sweet and welcoming. I love the dollar bills plastered all over the walls. Check this place out ! You won't be disappointed.
author: Marc E.

description: The bar is decent. There are one dollars bills everywhere on the ceiling and the wall. The bartenders are nice. A drunk man tried to nail a bartender and talked crap to her. I think that s not a review but just wanna share a story.
author: Mark T.

description: Looking for a dive bar with great service and a hugely interesting "clientele"?   Then look no further than High Tide.  I intentionally stay within walking distance of High Tide as it is always on my list of must visits when I'm in SFO.  Inexpensive drinks, great beer selection and an awesome bartender makes this a real neighborhood gem
author: Michael B.

description: Talk about rude. I walked in with friends for the first time visiting this place. First, she accused me of using a fake ID...really? I showed her two different forms of ID. I ordered a vodka soda. Whatever was given to me was very sweet so I took my drink to the bar and politely asked for a vodka soda. The bartendress scoffed at me and loudly asserted, "NO - your ordered ginger soda." And I said, "No, I said vodka soda please". She said, "NO, you said ginger soda". A bit shocked at this terrible customer service I said, "I never order a ginger-anything so I know the word didn't come out of my mouth. Can I have a vodka soda?" She refused. Honestly, what I should have pointed out was the obvious language barrier with a server that didn't understand or speak English well. How terribly rude for an establishment to argue with patrons when they are in the wrong. This bitch sucks.
author: Renee R.

description: May favorite bar on Geary Street in SF. Total dive bars with a great combination of locals and visitors. The bartenders are friendly and atmosphere is great! Be sure to stop in here if in the area!
author: Sabrina S.

description: For a drive bar, the drinks are not cheap, and best not order anything other than shots and beer there as I highly suspect that they water down their gin and vodka there.
author: C J.

description:
Loud ass trance/house music at a dive?!  Yea, I was kinda bewildered by that, especially since the only people in there on a quiet evening was an old, rocker lookin' dude and the bartender.  As it turned out, the old dude was trying to impress the bartender with his music savviness.  Did it work, not sure, didn't stay long enough.

But $7 call drinks really ain't that bad since anywhere else you go in the area will usually sport a $10/drink pricetag.  2 drinks is all one really should do here, but we stuck around for number 3 cuz after the onslaught of house music, the old dude switched over to old school AC/DC.  And very few things go together, like Bon Scott AC/DC and whisky (drink du jour), so we indulged in the extra drink.  Yea, that's what I thought, rocker old dude, you ain't  foolin' anybody with your House music.  *scoffs*
author: D.wight L.

description: Before I gave up the barfly life, I use to go there all the time.  As long as you keep drinking and dole out more dole.  Some people get too moralistic about this kind of life, it might be called meaningless after some time.  When your clock stops, it's end time.  This was my hangout and dive.  Then some of the hostesses got a little bit too snappy during conversations, then I brained out completely from this life.  But bars/dives are fun until it finally ends.  One advice, guys.  Don't try to marry off the hostess.  But I always admired that painting on the wall, it's been there forever.
author: BanBan B.

description:
Internet jukebox, strong drinks, pool table. 

Thank you Yelp for telling me that this review is shorter than most. I'll just keep typing until that notification goes away.

Someone outside has a blow off valve.

Yesssss. My review is now long enough. Happy Sunday!
author: Adam V.

description: very weird place.  never seen so many intense people staring at a tv, yet seeming so disconnected.  the drinks were way to small for the price.  felt very weird there.  and not because it was dirty.
author: Brian K.

description:
To sum it up: Divey divey dive dive
Returnability: Every couple of months
Superstar Factor: Not a superstar. Not even remotely close. Even reality shows would have to think twice. Kinda like the Bai Ling of bars... in a nice sort of way. But, so epic.

San Francisco dive bar test: mama-san bartenders (check), cowboy who works here (check), guy with girlfriend making out with a dude in the bathroom (check), E-40 (check), pool table (check), and guy who puts quarter on pool table (check). So epic.
author: Jess C.

description:
Hi-Tide Lounge is a dive bar but appropriately priced so the locals can't afford to drink here. place is clean, no barf evident,  no drunks, no 'ho's (wouldn't know one if i saw one)

amenities:
-pool table
-flatscreens tuned to sports
-smiling bartender. (chershire's cousin)
-english literate
-electronic jukebox.

drinks: 
-gin& tonic(5)
ok till the ice melts
-bud bottle @3.50, 6 micros on tap. 

0n draught:
-pricing like a regular bar, not dive pricing.
-parking meters suck. open on sundays.
3.5 stars......
author: Victor G.

description:
I love a good dive bar, but being a dive bar doesn't mean you have to be dirty. This place is disgusting and don't recommend touching anything at the risk of catching something. 

The pool table is awkwardly placed and it's difficult to play. And the drinks are kinda overpriced for being so divey.

I will stick to other bars and pass on ever going back.
author: Judie R.

description:
A true All-American dive bar.  We were wandering near our hotel and this was the first bar we came across.  

This place reeked of skeezy old dude with overly made-up old women hanging on their arms.  But since I was on vacation, I felt like this was something I should stick around and watch.

There's a juke box, and I promptly fed in a few bucks and requested songs by Ludacris and 50 Cent.  I got tired of Neal Diamond and the like.

Drinks are cheap.

The few booths are busted.  Duct tape covers the seats, and the table height was about right for the cast of "Little People Big World."

Totally worth visiting for the experience.
author: Angela P.

description:
I love dive bars, and this one is essential. The ladies tending the bar are incredibly sweet and accommodating. 

They've got a pool table which is something I tend to look for when going to a bar. (Not the best placement with the walls, but still great.) 

All in all, I love this place. And, when tunes are being played -- they are always on point... Only reason I'm giving it 4 stars is because it is cash only. (Luckily there is an ATM either at the pizza place next door or the hotel/apartment complex two doors down)
author: Hannah M.

description: The High Tide Lounge is just the sort of faded neighborhood dive bar I love ... Debbie Palmer and I visited to drink before a reservation at Millennium across the street  while visiting the City, Up from LA ...  On the juke box, Rod Stewart crooned bizarre calypso covers ... The bartender ~ fantastic, the Budweiser ~cold; the torn vinyl booths ~ set my imagination off .... "And none of them snooty beers ..."  True Detective
author: Brian W.

description: Gotta love this dive. I must say that next time i venture out here to frisco I gotta hit this local watering hole. CHEERS!!!! Went to my usual Frisco go to bar (chelsea place), met a local Kat that brought me, and my fam bam here to this dive and let me say.......CHEEEEERS!. THIS BAR IS MENT FOR THE ROUGH NECKS. STINKEN CHUMPS , STEER CLEAR!
author: Edward V.

description: The bartenders are from hanoro bar on geary street the girls are older and try to trick costumers to buy them drinks don't buy them any thing ok 10 buck for a small shot equals to 2 to 3  beers so be careful.also if they tell you that they are single that's a lie so be careful to all the tourist
author: Oswald m.

description: A bloody mary in a 10 oz glass for $10?? No, thanks. Didn't even include a piece of celery. Music was inappropriately loud for 230pm with only five patrons in attendance. There are far better dive bars in the area. Don't waste your time with this clip joint.
author: Michele N.

description: Solid dive bar with a good juke box. Not like the trendy bullshit across the street.
author: Mitch D.

description:
Casholla only, but there's an ATM near by.  We stopped in for one drink and were among just a few nice folks (it was a weeknight, by the way).  It's too bad that we had to head somewhere else and meet up with our friends.  I could have seen myself staying in this place for the whole evening. 

 It meets the two important qualifications for a "dive":  Dollar bills stapled everywhere and a painting of naked lady behind the bar.  The bartender was fully dressed and and as friendly as they come, for someone wearing all of their clothes.
author: Will L.

description:
Great little dive bar. Bartenders were two women that seemed to be enjoying themselves with the clientele. They were even handing out little free sandwiches to us! The bar is covered in interesting decor, including dollar bills and a framed picture of a topless woman. There is also an old school telephone booth tucked away in the back. 

The one thing that I was a bit surprised by was the prices.. they're not very divey.. $7 for a mixed drink, $5 for a beer. I suppose that's the price you have to pay for the location. CASH ONLY!

Overall, fun dive bar.
author: Peter H.

description: This is my very first visit to a bar, especially playing pool. I know that I'm not a drinker but they do have sodas which it is still a drink to have a good time.
author: Juan Z.

description:
This is the best dive-bar I've ever been to.
Me and my buddy were walking around, bar hopping on our last night in Frisco. As we walked around I saw people walking with what looked like personal pizza boxes. So I started to crave pizza. We eventually found the pizza joint next to this place. After finding out the pizza place was open until 3AM, we walked into the Hi-Tide to ramp up our hunger with beers. The bartenders were friendly and fun. They had a juke-box but some regular had backed up the playlist with hip-hop songs...it was last call before my first song started to play.
There were some tourists here from different parts of the world, they were all friendly making the place feel more like a party, with everyone bouncing around and talking to each other.
I wanna move to San Francisco just to be a regular here.
author: Frankie D.

description:
Overall- Convenient little corner dive bar on the way into the Tenderloin. The bar was divey without being trashy, helped along by the 2 sweet (if a little distracted) older Korean ladies bar tending. CASH ONLY

Crowd-  Relaxed, mostly groups of friends out for a drink, no one was overly rowdy or obnoxious. Occasional people coming in off the street to ask for money, but not overbearing. 

Other- It has a pool table up front, unfortunately jammed into a room a little too small so shots from the side were difficult/impossible. Your pool cue has to be angled up like you're spearing fish. 

Would get drunk there for cheap again if I was in the neighborhood. Wouldn't travel far if there were other options available.
author: Patrick T.

description: Chill Tenderloin dive. Pool table. Opens early. Classy nude painting behind the bar. Cash only. Surprisingly good beer on tap.
author: Patrick S.

description:
This is a dive bar.  I totally get that.  However, there are plenty of dive bars that are fun , and this is not one of them.  We played pool and get this, they don't have an 8 ball, but they do have an extra ball.  So, during our game we kept reminding each other that the "dirty" stripe was our "8."  The music was terrible and not in a hipster ironic way.

I'm giving this place two stars instead of one because of the bartender/waitress that came over to me and told me I should play pool with my purse on instead of leaving it on the stool by the pool table.  For a split second I thought that was a little excessive, but then I thought, "Well, this is the TL and she should know.... so..."  (As an aside, I blame my barely losing the game to my balance being thrown off because of said purse.)

Well, I'm glad I listened to her.  Not 5 minutes later, in walks some riff-raff, crazy guy.  (Not judging, just describing.)  He starts harrasing/begging to this couple that were waiting to play pool and then he came over to us, and then we promptly left.  Given what the bartender said to me, (and I'm grateful), I take it that this kind of thing happens on a regular basis.

Oh, and it smelled a little bit.  I'm not sure what the smell was and I really don't want to know... but it was there.
author: Chloe M.

description:
Pros- kind of inexpensive.

Cons- kind of- (and I'm being modest) it is a shit hole! What's up with all the one dollar bills on the walls and ceiling?

I think you can get a prostitute here.
author: Farty M.

description:
Never again will I go here!  The place is really run down!  Service wasn't good or really bad

When I went, there was this guy there (and I have to assume he was drunk), and he was staring at my friend and I really bad.  It was almost scary.  My husband was ready to fight this guy, it was that bad.  This guy then began to do it to all the women in there.  The bartenders asked him to sit in the back corner far away from everyone.  The fact they didnt ask him to leave was the final straw for me.  

Oh, and the drinks are over priced!
author: Anna T.

description:
This was the diviest dive bar that we came across while in San Francisco.  Given it was right across the street from our hotel.  The music selection is definitely limited.  It was never too crowded when we were there.  The bartenders are friendly and always had a supply of popcorn.  But not popcorn as we know it, but Korean popcorn which is apparently made from hamony.

And you definitely know it is a dive bar when you see a 50 something drunk Asian woman flirting with a 20 something white guy then they leave together.  Then about 15 minutes later the Asian lady comes back and has another drink and starts chatting it up with the bartender.  It makes you think.
author: Zach P.

description:
This is probably my favorite dive bar in the city. I've been here on & off for a while now, and have always loved it. We came in here on St. Paddy's Day for the celebration of my stepsister's 21st birthday (yes, her birthday is actually March 17th). I forewarned them about the place, but she LOVED it. We made friends, got down to the jukebox, and had lots of drinks. It was a good night.

That is until some weird hipsters walked in and within 10 minutes a brawl broke out, literally. It was hilarious watching a hipster try to fight a big, burly drunk dude. Maybe you shouldn't have been talking shit about his girlfriend, hipster kid in the argyle sweater....

But please, could you freakin' hipsters leave the damned place alone?! I'd like for your d-bags to NOT invade every inch of the city... Leave at least something untouched by your hipsterness. Ugh.

Anyway - the place is awesome. Relatively inexpensive drinks, an awesome jukebox, and USUALLY a great crowd. Oh, there's also a pool table. Check it out!
author: Jennifer V.

description:
To be perfectly honest, when I go out to drink, I'm not out to meet people. I'm either catching up with friends or hiding in the wretched foreskin of my experiential stream, if you will. I don't need to rub elbows with the sweating masses or bump erections with a Friday night, a crowded room our bank of the mighty river Ka-blonk. 

Sure, I'd like some cheap drinks, but you know what, so does everyone else. As long as a fiver buys and tips, and there's maybe a booth for me and another friend or two, folks that like to keep it to themselves or commiserate or warmly celebrate small victories without desperation or rage in their voices, or exorcize fear, insecurities and loathing without hate, then we're in good company. 

And this place is just a good ol' dive with a pool table, juke box (sometimes a little too loud), gnarled regulars, the odd painting or two, and the random maniac that wanders in from the street. It ain't pretty, and it ain't always quiet or not-crowded, but more often than not, it is quiet and not crowded, and those are pretty decent odds. I'm not saying, Go Here. That's not what I'm saying. I'm saying 3 stars because it's a solid bar for what it is. But don't. Come. Hither.
author: Roy M.

description:
I hate hi-tide because there has not been a time that I've left here sober or questioned if I've just caught aids from the bar patron that's sitting next to me. 

Also, I hope you aren't easily offended because there IS indeed a painting of the owner (the petite korean lady I believe) topless. 

I think it's quaint....

I definitely miss this bar. Filled with good times, screaming, debauchery, and blurry train rides home.
author: Thao L.

description:
Broken pool table
Painting of topless lady
Cheap drinks, shattered dreams
author: Jonathan C.

description: Bingo, bingo, bingo.  And did I mention free Bingo jello shot?  SO much fun!
author: Maddy S.

description:
Dive bar to me means same smelly drunkards at the bar every night, being able to smoke cigs even though it's against state law, going to the men's room and snorting coke off some greasy Mexican's house key, and making out and fist fighting the hot Korean bartender that drinks too much. I will respect her enough to not say her name, but if you've been here then you know who I'm talking about.

Well, this was Hi-Tide when I knew it and these are the things that I remembered happening there before I got kicked out for hitting the hot bartender. Couple of years ago I walked in tried to light a cig and was quickly stopped by the bartender. You can't smoke there anymore. So, I walked out.

Went back recently and this is a totally new bar! Flashing lights, hipster music on blast and of course it was full of these new hipster kids that are invading the city! All I saw was a swarm of White kids standing outside smoking and I knew I would have to let Hi-Tide go once and for all.

Eight years ago Hi-Tide would have gotten all 5 of my stars, but today I know that they've sold out to a crowd that is changing our city for the worst.

Bye-Bye Hi-Tide. You will always hold a special place in my heart, the old you anyway.
author: Camille R.

description:
This little dive did a great job entertaining me one night while I was visiting SF and didn't want to go far from my hotel.

*Great Jukebox
*Cheap Drinks
*Almost totally neglected pool table allowing for maximum play time

All and all, what's not to like.
author: Dan C.

description:
Loud juke box filled with classics + Fat tire on tap+ sticky sofa seating+ naked girl picture behind bar + barmaids who seem like they might be employed at the nearby asian massage parlor OH YEAH I SAID IT + leering sexual predators at the bar + having your beer snatched out of your hands by the Madame I mean bartender at exactly 1:59:59 AM + your after-party friend calling the bartender a cunt and then running out the door losing a shoe

  =
    
AWESOME DIVE BAR
author: Jay Z.

description:
This dive bar on Geary and Jones has become a favorite of mine.  The bartenders are friendly, they serve good drinks and make you feel at home.  No food, but there are places all around it that have pizza and even chinese.

They have a juke box to play all your favorite songs.  Pool table if thats your thing.  But most of all the people that hang here are friendly....
author: Kenneth G.

description:
:(

I have no recollection of returning a meal until today. Much less twice.  My hubby picked me up for lunch saying he had a craving for a burger and knew of a place he'd been to a year or two back. 

So we arrived at Hi-Tide drooling for a tasty burger. I ordered a cappuccino (tasty) and we ordered some calamari as an appetizer (huge portion, also tasty). Then we ordered our burgers, no frills, cooked medium-well. Our waitress was really nice.

Our burgers came and we were hungry to satisfy our cravings. They were hardly cooked at all, mine especially. I sheepishly went to the waitress saying that my burger wasn't cooked enough. She was very nice and took the burgers back and brought us new ones. My husbands burger was perfect...I took a bite of mine and knew it was again hardly cooked. 

My assumption is half the grill wasn't as hot as the other. 

I ended up returning the second burger and didn't ask for a replacement. We ended up sharing, but the craving wasn't satisfied. Our waitress claimed that it was their new cook's first day and that it would probably be his last. Will I return one day? Maybe...but I have no idea when...
author: Jennifer P.

description: How does one rate Hi-Tide? I mean, it's one of the dumpiest bars in Union Square, which is what makes this so appealing. It's cheap, with limited hard alcohol selections. It's covered in dollar bills from drunk tourists leaving their mark. Clientele is all over the map, with local and foreigners alike playing the juke box and watching small televisions in the corners. They have a pool table and crappy bathrooms. I love this place.
author: David B.

description: Cheap drinks, chill atmosphere, and incredible bartenders! The ladies working here make sure we have a blast every time we come in. For the most part, San Francisco's bartenders are either aging hipsters under the illusion that their on top of a stage rather than behind a bar or haughty "mixologists" looking to justify the dust on their art degree. Vicky and her crew are the opposite of this and that makes them awesome...
author: Ryan S.

description:
When I first stumbled upon Hi Tide, I was excited that it was a dive.The bar was empty. There were people huddled in booths. There was a juke-box. A pool table. It had character and had an abundance of characters.

But once I started to take a closer look at it all - I started to get a little bothered.

Someone was blowing smoke in my eyes. The juke-box was screeching out a painful song. The drinks weren't so cheap. They didn't take credit cards. And suddenly all of a sudden the characters around me started to look dazed. Their eyes glazed over. I felt unsettled. Started feeling like Hi-Tide had come and gone - so I left. 

That night I realized I'd left my wallet somewhere. I called up bar after bar. I couldn't  remember Hi Tide's name, being that we'd only stumbled upon it by accident. When it finally came to me - I called them up. They said they had my wallet so I trekked over there. 

All of my cash was gone, as was my bus pass, and I ended up cancelling all of my cards (though thankfully I had my ID). The bartender, who gave me back my wallet was nice enough.

I adore dive bars. I love them. And I know Hi-Tide is supposed to be right up there, but I think I'll have to come back on another night. Sing along to the juke-box, maybe play some pool, and toast a drink or two - before I can call this a four star dive.
author: Jessica T.

description: The first place I got drunk in SF, many years ago. Nothing's changed since then. The pool table is in good shape, but as Patrick T. said, set up in a small room so that you can't fully draw back for a shot from many angles of the table. Bummer, but cheap beer and nice service.
author: Sonya Z.

description: One star for crappy service and the drink was overpriced for a dive bar I should of stayed at Gino and Carlos in North Beach.   I walked in on a Saturday afternoon, the old Korean woman working behind the bar bypassed me several times as she was more interested with her doing shots and serving her male customers.   Finally, by the time she got to me, I got a weak overpriced drink.
author: Rambo M.

description:
Definition of a dive bar. Across the street from the Ambassador which is a popular loung/bar place. 

The bartenders are a pair of asian women that aren't shy when it comes to taking shots with customers. Their always smiling and laughing and very friendly. Crowd is pretty grungy and old. Its got a nice jukebox and some booths to sit at. 

Not a crazy party scene, but no lines, cheap booze, and a jukebox. Can't go wrong with that.
author: Arthur C.

description: Well, it's a dive bar. What do you expect. To me there's definitely a nostalgic attraction. My sister used to live just across the street and I've heard great stories of her husband just heading in there to catch a giants game and coming home with some insane story of who he met. You meet interesting characters all day long. I've been here countless times with buddies we'd grab pizza next door and bring it in the bar. Watch a game or play pool. So much so that the bartender recognizes me even though I live in Portland. I recommend heading in on a weekend night to wrap up or start your night. It's fun, right on the corner and cheap. Cash only though.
author: Michael R.

description: This place is now surrounded by really nice bars that have all opened in the past five years.  I hate really nice bars, so I come to a place that has a touch of class from the 70's.  Beer and a shot please.
author: Corey V.

description: What's with all these TL dives with Asian ladies running the spot? OG Asian ladies that don't really realize their age? LOL...yeah I said it! There's a cute, lil' young one that works here too though. She can get a bit wild at times and act more like bar folk more than bar staff. All good. Still a fun spot for drinks, crappy jukebox music, and pool. I come here frequently because it's right around the way. I come her frequently because I got mad folks that come here. I come her frequently because they never carded my BFF when she wasn't of drinking age yet (shhhhh!). One of my homegirls did get into a full-on fist fight with the cute Asian bartender once. I wasn't there for that and I'm happy I wasn't cuz I probably would've been all up in it and got 86ed.
author: Helen L.

description: Definitely a dive, but has great service. The bartender yuki Is amazing she is very friendly but will also tell you about the city. Love this bar!!!!!
author: Ashley B.

description:
friday 4pm sunset searching for those hidden places in the sunset finds me and my girl @ the TIDE...

it has the look of a historic old SF bar with the velvet drapes and old timer sailor painting...it was early friday happy hour, they had some simple tasty lasagna, it got local peeps busy and active and we had a good time...

my lone critique is that there beer tap and bottle selection is weak at best for an SF bar...me like beer and why cant they at least have some decent beer bottles in the inventory?
author: alex m.

description:
I love this bar.
So many good times.
She always mix my drinks with whatever I feel like.
All the dollar notes are fun, they have cheep beer, even german ones like becks.
The jukeboy is great.
It's an old dive bar, dont expect to much but its a great escape from all that fancy hipster bars at jones.

Rock'n'Roll
author: feli p.

description:
True story. 

A bunch of us were out in the city one rainy winter night in '05 or '06, a time when I was living in Oakland and in fact was still new to the Bay area, so a night out in San Francisco was still something along the lines of special. Anyway, we got dinner somewhere, sushi I think on Post, and got tipsy enough to decide to make a whiz-bang night of it. At the time, this meant heading to the Owl Tree (rest in peace; I refuse to call the current decolletage-drenched establishment the same Owl Tree run by C. Bobby (rest, again, in peace you lovely curmudgeon)), which we did, but which was muy crowded and therefore untenable for we thirtysomething curmudgeons-in-training*. So where to next?, we wondered. Figuring Geary to be a better option than most we headed downhill along Taylor and looked both ways. 

Now, currently the picture on Yelp for this bar is of the Hi-Tide's signage, which is, um, inviting to certain types of sots. My friends and I were then, and pretty much still are now, exactly those sots, and now that I think about it I believe it was that night when we made the rule that any bar with a neon martini glass outside of it, olived or no, is worth seeing the inside of. Moth-like, we flitted over and saw the inside of it, taking up shop in a booth right by the bar.

A couple whiskeys in and we got to thinking about the weed that one of us so happened to be carrying on his person (kind of a rarity, unlike with many of our fellow Bay Areans^). Another of us so happened to be carrying rolling papers--ibid. as to being a rarity--and the next thing we knew we were...crumbling the weed onto the table and getting it ready for a joint. Which we rolled. At that table, which was, I feel compelled to remind you, right in front of the bar, and by "right" I mean "two feet" and by "in front" I mean "away," so, yeah, two feet from the bar, rolling a joint. 

Furthermore, I believe I mentioned we a) were drunk, and b) not normally given to this sort of behavior, public or otherwise. Which is to say, it took us, you know, several minutes to put this thing together. But put it together we did, and to celebrate such a feat we decided to, alley oop, light it, the feat, right there at the table, that same table "right" "in front" of the bar. Because, why not?

Yeah, so we were semi-ceremoniously shooed out of the bar by the fiftysomething semi-English-speaking barmaid, to which request we acquiesced to a minimum standard. By that I mean we stepped outside and smoked the joint on the street  **right beneath that glorious, glorious sign**  and then walked right back in as if nothing happened. 

Of course, telling this story now, in 2012, when, eg, it's more illegal in New York City to carry around a Big Gulp filled with Coke than one filled with weed, this seems like no big deal. But to me, then, fresh off the train from the midwest where it was fifty degrees colder and fifty thousand billion times less hospitable to public joint-rolling and -smoking, it was one more reason to call this town Heaven. 

But it's still a dive bar and a dump inside and actually kind of depressing, depending on when you go, so you get 3 stars, Hi-Tide, because you're A-OK.


*Along these lines, my friends and I subscribe to Esquire's Rule #1478 (or whatever number it is): No one ever sits in a bar and thinks, You know what, the music could actually be *louder*. 

^Yikes; that sure sounds a lot like Bay Aryans.
author: T U.

description: My new day time beer spot, I'd be in here everyday if I lived here. Friendly bartender during the day. Gets a bit hipsterish at night.
author: Mike S.

description:
God I love dive bars. And this is no exception in the loving Tender-Nob hood. My first time I was here was by accident 'cause Bourbon and Branch was booked but I'm not disappointed! Quite the contrary. I feel so at home with the old men drinking their whiskey from the tap practically, the locals who don't have any interests other than what's in their bucket. 
The restroom is upstairs, pretty clean and even smells nice. Can you believe that?
The jukebox is a little old but it's got a good selection of classics.
Drinks are strong, beers are cheap, and the bartender is cute and Korean. 
I spotted the owner show a girl how to do a booty shake. Awesome. Will be back again.
author: Jessica K.

description:
Cheap beer

Cool vibe

Pool table is crammed in but fun

Decent juke box

Hobos coming in off streets stealing money off counter
author: Brennan M.

description: This joint was ok until the Koreans took it over.Then it turned into a home for lonely guys.
author: David B.

description: Love this place.  Super divey. Pit bull sitting on a bar stool next to her owner.  Me and my man drinking suprisingly good margaritas at the bar. Potato chips every now and then. My favorite Sunday afternoon hang out.
author: Maya S.

description:
#131

After dinner at Katana-Ya, my friends and I were looking for a bar or lounge close by. We already weren't in a club-type mood since we had sat in the rain for four hours at the Emerald Bowl (Thankfully, USC pulled out the victory). We decided to hit up a close dive bar, found courtesy of the yelp iPhone app.

There seemed to be a bunch of regulars because both bartenders knew quite a few by name. I'd saw that the overall crowd was a tad on the older side. A few younger groups passed through looking for a restroom, and some just wanted to grab a cheap drink on the way to their next stop.

There was also a jukebox, playing mainly 50s & 60s music. I think I heard Britney Spears on the way out, however. I'm glad that didn't come on until we were leaving. There is also a pool table. I didn't get a good look at it since there was a party playing the entire time we were there ... but I guess the point I'm trying to make is that they have one.

The prices seemed pretty cheap. Although I don't have the per drink breakdown, $16 bought me:
-7 and 7
-pint of Bass draft
-bottle of Corona

The bartenders were pretty nice, giving us some freshly popped popcorn. Even though it was probably only microwavable, it sure was nice to snack on something while drinking.

Overall, it was a nice spot to grab a few drinks. The only thing that irked me was that they accept cash only. It wasn't pretentious at all and had a dive-y feel without looking like they were trying. It was just what we were looking for.
author: Brandon A.

description:
Broke up with one of my best friends here.

In the middle of the tearful death of an 11 year friendship, a drunk crack head felt the need to explain to us his life's troubles. Couldn't understand a damn thing he was saying to us.

Good times, man. Good times.
author: Jay H.

description:
It's an ok dive bar. Not really cheap like a dive. The cute little asian bartender is super sweet though. 

It's funny, this place is usually my first stop with friends before we do our TL bar adventures, however I ALWAYS see some random guys in nice -just-got-off-of-work attire with some young girls who obviously aren't from the city and has no business dating these douchy looking gentlemen. And they always try to get the cute girl and their friends drunk.. I'm sure this happens at almost every bar it's just weird to me. Seeing guys try to act all super money bags and they take girls to Hi-Tide. That alone deserves a star right there.

Theres better dives in the city. Its an ok place to meet friends- but if you want a SF dive crawl- cross this off your list.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Best place on earth for a million reasons:

-bartenders
-decor
-tourists
-jukebox
author: Alison C.

description: Much less sketchy than I expected. The place smelled slightly odd at first - a companion likened it to chlorine, but I found it to be something much less "clean," but this seemed to wear off - or I sustained neurological damage, who knows. The TVs are kind of small and not too clear, but good enough for monday night football. To be honest, the pool table is  poorly situated, making for some tough shots, but overall the place is pretty decent and fun.
author: Lisa K.

description:
O, Hi-Tide Lounge, I expected more from you, with your flashy neon martini-glass sign. I have walked by you numerous times, always with the assumption that you were dark inside, and more sinister. But alas, you are not. Maybe you were at some point, but you are not now.

Another disappointingly well-lit "dive" bar. I think the modern-looking green lights are recently-installed, and I can only imagine how much better it would be without them, especially with that faux-stone wall littered with foreign currency. But other aesthetic touches were perfect - the floor was filthy, the red carpeting on the side of the bar was held together with duct tape, and then there was the painting. The proudly displayed centerpiece of the bar, a painting of a lady of unknown Asiatic descent, draped partially in a white feather boa, her right breast unashamedly exposed. My complete disinterest in breasts aside, I found this to be the best feature of this establishment.

The booths with tiny tables were an interesting feature, upon which we noticed that some people were eating a mysterious green substance from a red basket. Apparently the bar snacks here are not the traditional pretzels and nuts, but some sort of dried seaweed snack.

We also liked the unexplained window in the stairway leading to the lavatory. I made Lady Pestlebottom wave to me from it on her way to relieve herself. 

Other than those unique touches, I found this to be quite a boring drinking establishment. Mainly due to the patronage, which consisted of university student-types, and young boring persons of several ethnicities. Several youngsters were playing billiards, which is not our cup of tea. The overall mood was jovial, in a completely uninteresting way. 

The music that was played from the juke-box was insufferable, ranging from the horrible modulated-voice dance music, to Mexican ballads, to Britney Spears to The Doors. An odd assortment. Lady Pestlebottom was confused and horrified that I was able to identify a Britney Spears song within the first five notes. Or at all. 

What I'm endlessly searching for is the type of tavern in which one can barely see one's hand in front of one's face for the reddened darkness, and the purpose of which is to drink sullenly and quietly at the end of the bar, lamenting the futility of life until last call, or at least until one passes out in one's bourbon. And also the type of place in which one could discreetly give or receive a hand job at the bar without another's notice or care. Alas, this place was none of those things. 

As for other reviewer's remarks about smoke and urine odors, I noticed neither (well, there was a urine odor in the bathroom, where it's supposed to be). I expected cigarette-smoking to be going on, but mercifully, there was none.
author: Mortimer P.

description:
Have you ever been in love? I hadn't been until I met Kim, Hi-Tide's bouncer/bartender. 

She is probably the best bartender in San Francisco. She's a real people person and has a great sense of humor. Everyone needs to party with her at least once. 

Also, the bar has a sweet neon sign outside. I cant remember what it says but I know I liked it.
author: Bobby P.

description: Maybe it is because the bartender thought I was famous or a model, maybe it was the three other bars, maybe it was the naked painting behind the bar.  Well, whatever it was, I enjoyed my stay here and will be back.  Dive bars are so fun.
author: Synnora B.

description:
Holy crap? I haven't reviewed this place yet? Wow, I am clearly slippin (off my chair after a drink here)

So last night, my buddy Sean and I hit up the House of Shields and ran into a co-worker and pretty much crashed his date (Sorry about that, Steve). We then all got to talking about what makes for a good dive bar and instantly, the Hi-Tide Lounge popped into my head. 

For me a good dive bar should have most of these elements...

-Old men drinking booze without mixers
-A bar top your elbows will stick to
-A "we don't really give a shit" attitude by the bartender, but friendly at the same time
-Some sort of really bad neon beer sign that is burned out in a few places on the neon strips
-Locals only
-A really bad bathroom, often missing toilet paper and definitely without toilet seat covers
-No friggin hipsters

If you can muster up a few of those, then i think you fairly should receive the "Dive Bar" crown and rock it. Hi-Tide definitely rocks all of these elements and also has books on the honor system here that they will pretty much let you borrow and then bring back without question. I still have Mussles: A Novel by Phillip Quinn Morris on my desk here at work. One of my co-workers "borrowed" it about a year and a half ago and has yet to return it, but don't worry Hi-Tide, I will bring it back to you one of these days :) Promise.
author: Stephy S.

description:
Monday - Dive Bar with strong cheap drinks
Tuesday - Drug Den with slow service
Wednesday - Asian Hostess Bar with good service
Thursday - Yuppie Bar with weak drinks
Friday - Garage Sale (yes, the homeless will wander in and try to sell you things like broken hairdryers)
Saturday - Gay Bar
Sunday - Dance club with no dance floor

*Note - any of these days can be interchanged here. You really never know what you are going to get.

Extra star for the fine art hanging behind the bar.
author: Drue C.

description:
Hands-down, this is the most disturbing bar I have ever visited. My date and I came here last night. I'm not sure why, but I think that we may both be a little bit sick in the head. 

Ambiance? Nope. I'm pretty sure that ambiance was not in the vocabulary of whomever decorated this place. Actually, they probably didn't even HAVE a vocabulary. We decided pretty promptly that the Hi-Tide is a living creature, that sustains on the sadness and perversion of others.

There's something tragic and gross about this bar, and that makes it all the more entertaining. Who ARE the people here? Do they live nearby? Are they passing through? Nearly everyone in here was single, and not the proud single that you often see out at bars, but the sad, slightly drunk, gonna go home and beat off to some foot fetish videos later kind. 

I'm pretty sure the bartender hated me. A lot of female bartenders deal with scary drunk men, but don't enjoy the attention. This woman, however, seemed to truly enjoy the adoration she was getting. I ordered a Jack and Coke that was $6 and mostly Coke. Actually, I think it was DIET Coke. We watched in amazement as the bartender lovingly stroked and massaged a hulking old gentleman's paw. She cooed and blinked her eyes and acted like a little girl. I wonder if she learned to do that at the "massage" joint across the street. The gentleman left the bar, but not before leaving her a $50 tip. 

Yeah.

The jukebox here is a time machine. I'm sure of it! I didn't even feel like I was in San Francisco. It seemed like we were at a bar just off of the freeway somewhere in the southwest. And with Elton John's "Rocket Man" blaring on the jukebox, anything was possible. At the end of the bar, two sad-looking men sat together and commiserated. We sat across the room, watching and silently willing the men to kiss before the song ended.

There is a painting behind the bar of a shirtless woman with a bad perm. She is surrounded by what looks like feathers, but it could also be a dead poodle. 

I left this bar feeling like I'd just gotten my brain re-wired. There's seriously and truly something wrong with the Hi-Tide, and I like it a lot.
author: Pamela D.

description: The only high tide in this place is the level of piss on the bathroom floor.
author: Mark A.

description:
One Pool table +1
You can smoke inside +3
Bartenders - Not so good looking  -1
Didn't know how to make a Buttery Nipple shot  -2



Total Score: 1 Star
author: MJ T.

description: Fun faux dive bar in the party section of Tenderloin-ish.. They have that "write and post your dollar bill" tradition and a sexy painting up behind the bar. No Stella for some reason!
author: Conor M.

description: Dude this place is a great dive bar. I felt at home. Went on a Sunday and the bartender was super friendly. I tipped good and she bought me a drink. She took pictures of me and my girlfriend. With an, "of course baby' as an answer to each request. Really cool vibe.
author: Edward E.

description: I used to go there quite a bit about 4 or 5 years ago. The bartenders were fun and it had a somewhat speakeasy feel to it due to being full of smoke and gambling. The owner Sandy is a nice lady. After they were busted for the umteenth time for letting people smoke, the crowds just simply became skid row. If I'm paying $7 for a shot of jagermeister, I'd rather go in to a nicer bar down the street like Swig, Rye or Bourbon and Branch. As of Tenderloin Bars, I'm a bigger fan of Whiskey Theives and Harrington's down near the Civic Center.
author: Out O.

description:
Pirate Pub Crawl bar #7

Well, who can really trust the word of a drunken sailor at this point in the evening?  Capn Keith led us here, and the ladeez behind the bARRRR seemed attentive, but at this point, all I could do was take in the scenery.  I recall some quasi-porno decor, which I'll have to give 5 stARRRs to.

I'll have to come back another time, but this is a good barrrrr, as I recall.
author: Andi T.

description: You know it's good when there are strands of working Christmas lights installed over the older, burnt out ones.
author: Corey H.

description: I love this bar.  The bartenders are hot, the jukebox is fun, and the pool table takes you back to the 70's. One guy looks like Fonzie, the gay couple Don and Lando are hilarious, and there's a cool tribute to people who died from AIDS on the dollar bills hung on the walls.  Gay icon Robert Harris is honored there.  The only time I really was repulsed is when someone took a dookie in the pisser.  Yep, a shiny brown brain was dumped in the urinal.  That was new.  Not everyday you see someone's insides in a urinal.  But hey, it's the Tenderloin, what are you going to do?
author: TJ B.

description:
Great dive bar, cheap drinks and they have a pool table!
   ***CASH ONLY***
Jukebox got some good mixes, no complaints.
Friendly bartenders, she almost kick a homeless ass for begging for change inside...  jeje
Really cool mix crowd.  Some cool tourist too!
author: Yamil A.

description: Popped in to get the hell out of the rain. It is that kind of place that you would not make a trip just to come to. Even at night, it took a while for my eyes to adjust to the darkess of the place. I left this bar in fear when I was 19-20 drinking here and was offered a vairety of controlled substances. The place really makes me claustrophobic for some reason. Didn't really see any hipsers, or drug dealers... so I guess that is good.
author: Jim B.

description:
My friend and I found this place after we found out Who's Your Daddy doesn't exist anymore (it is now a boarded up building. How very sad when a bar closes. It's like when a kitten falls of a cliff). Yeah, it's kind of a dive, and I like places like that for some reason. But it's enjoyable none the less. A cool place to be. However, the bartenders on some occasions have insulted me a little bit ... one saying they could "tell" I was an English-only speaking Filipino. The second one when I stumbled up to the bar and had a mind block ... I turned to some random dude, and I think he suggested a Long Island Iced Tea. "One of those," I mumbled. The bartender then went "UHHH???" I then put my arm around the guy, much to the dismay of his girlfriend right next to him. SCORE. Anyway, how DARE she question MY ability to pound a few?

But ... really. Nice place. I like watching episodes of "Roseanne" when I'm hammered.
author: Caroline L.

description:
After a long evening of spending $10 on mixed drink concoctions it's nice to take it down a notch at high-tide.  

the two times i've been here I've been provided with smokes - so I smoked.

The name rocks.  High-tide, dude.  

The service rocks in a t-loin sort of way.  

not much of a drink selection - just deal with it - this ain't tommy effin toys.

the waitstaff has soul, and I can't ask for anything more than that.  

The crowd rocks (way more lively, random, and energetic than the more sophisticated bourbon and branch set).  

The bathroom smells really really bad (just go in your pants).  

don't stay too long or your lungs will collapse.  Stay long enough to understand why the place is so great than go to either Shalimar or Chutney and swallow several pieces of naan to coat that surly stomach of yours.
author: chris o.

description:
I needed change for the bus, and decided I could also use a beer. 

Hi-Tide, I'd always wanted to check it out. 

Nothing special really. It's a dive (big surprise). The smell of cigarettes and urine is pretty intense, since you can still smoke in there from time to time from what I've heard and....well...maybe people pee on the floor? 

There's a beat up pool table and a jukebox that has a few good tunes in it. The regulars are an assortment of aging Tenderloin pro-drinkers and the occasional crackhead. 

So, yeah, I wouldn't make a special trip to the TL to go there, but if you're determined to visit every dive in the city then you should stop in.
author: Mark G.

description:
Every now and again you come across a bar you enjoy but you're not sure why. Everything about the place should turn you off to it, but for some reason you get this feeling "You know, I could see myself coming back here." High Tide Lounge is that spot.

The  bar is, without question, a dive. The decor is tacky, the bar itself a bit dingy, and just loud enough to hear yourself  think. Barely. The bartenders are a bit inattentive and the alcohol selection, while reasonably priced, is nothing special. And for some reason the entire place makes me think of casting out to port.

But you go here and something overtakes you. There's an energy and liveliness about bar, and a friendliness about the regulars and the first timers. You don't go to High Tide to relax with a beer, you go to  have  a good time with friends.

And maybe make a few new ones along the way.

Not  my number one spot in the city for drinks but certainly not at the bottom. High Tide Lounge can probably get itself bumped up to four stars if the service is better on my return visit.
author: Keith M.

description:
This is one of the coolest bars I have been to.
It isn't the drinks, it isn't the ambiance, not even the prices.
It is the people. 
My first trip to San Francisco I stumbled upon the Hi-Tide. And stumble out. I met some really cool people and only paid for one my drinks all night. I have been back a few times since and the faces change but not the hospitality and how great the people are. I met a Tahitian, a Mexican, some Irishmen, a Frenchmen, Korean, as well as SF locals and even a guy from where I live now, Phoenix, AZ.
The owner and bartender and great, too.
I always feel welcome and among friends here, something that is rare in this day and age.
I look forward to my return to San Francisco and I will be sure to stop in again.
author: Tim J.

description:
Let's start with the downside. 

Men's bathroom: scary. In fact, the only bathroom I've seen that compares is the men's bathroom in The Strand bookstore in NY, and that one had standing, um, water (I hope). But there's a novelty mystery door in the bathroom that is secured by what appears to be a string of chicken wire looped through the doorknob hole. So, if you're in need of a quick hiding place -- or you're hurting to relive the Choose Your Own Adventure days of your childhood -- you may consider this.

That said, I usually don't go to bars for the bathrooms. So, on to the upsides ...

The decor is classic neighborhood dive -- the behind-the-bar picture mentioned by other Yelpers, sturdy bar rail, dingy atmosphere minus actual dinge (outside of aforementioned restroom), a microwave (though no food to speak of), a pool table, and a surprisingly not crappy selection of tunes on the juke box. Also, they allow smoking, so I guess that means it's employee-owned.

We went  on a Friday afternoon, during the shift change, and one of the regulars bought us drinks. So, not too shabby.
author: Josh E.

description: Five-stars if you're waiting for someone to arrive into the city and you got some time to kill, but you may be asked to carry some boxes. Do it, you will be rewarded. The Chinese bartendress was a great source of info on sf dim sum spots (where there are no white people). By the way, I'm white. I liked it a lot, but it was the right time for it. Only go here if you need a few drinks and have no expectations, not if your main focus is hipster fashion, tattoos, or meeting a girl to bring home to mama. In fact, don't try to meet anyone here if your main pursuit is sexual.
author: Thomas R.

description:
My lord is this a dive. They only serve bottom-mid shelf booze. Want something nicer than Smirnoff? Don't even think about it. They also have a selection of "wells" below the counter that just have white labels that say "Vodka" or "Gin". Its almost like they're trying to scare you.'

Aside from that, the decor is great, the people are nice, and its a friendly and safe place to drink a Gordon's Gin and Tonic.
author: Matt C.

description:
Hilarious. Came here 1 year ago and the bar tender passed out. Back 12 months later, and she's asleep in one of the booths. 

Awesome juke box and cheap drinks. Totally down to earth. I'll be back on my next visit to SF. And I bet the bartender is still sleeping...
author: Dan P.

description:
I don't think this is a gay bar, but gay dudes do hang out here.  What this is is a drug den.  Lots o'wheeling and dealing going on.

EDIT:

You know what, as time goes on this place grows nearer and dearer to my heart.  I mean, it will almost certainly be my downfall, but I can't help it.  It's like my living room.  I will most certainly know somebody there no matter when I go.  And yeah, even though the bartenders more or less hate me, it's pretty much always an adventure.  Plus, I heart the big neon sign out front.

EDIT:

Jesus Christ.  First of all, I don't know who that Greta character is who's bitching about gangsters, but there are like never ever gangsters in there.  AND there's not even that much hip hop on the freaking jukebox.  I don't know where she was hanging out.  Secondly....THANK GOD I've finally been thrown out of here.  It was a long time coming, but it's finally happened, and I can only hope that I'm 86ed for good.  I need to be physically banned from here.  Before me only homeless people got thrown out.  Luckily I still have a home.
author: Coco D.

description: Inside, it's the epitome of a great dive. a shitty pool table. a few booths. dirty bathrooms. dark with strange things hanging on the wall. I come here every time i'm in SF and probably will go back. Ordered a shot of jameson and a tecate bottle and got charged 11.50. Counted my change back at the booth but by then it was too late. Something doesn't seem right with those prices. I put my shot glass in my pocket to somewhat even the score, got up, and left for better places down the street.
author: Tim O.

description:
Once i really liked this place, used to serve up some strong drinks, cheap and i could smoke there, since the "remodel" its gone downhill. 

I KNOW! kinda hard for a dive bar to go down hill but it has, drinks have gone way up, weaker pour as well, also no more smoking at the bar, so now i have to go outside and get hassled by jocks and hobos. krikey! 

So if your thinking of a great dive bar, look elsewhere this place is now just fair to middlin.
author: Cooper M.

description: Our nightcap(s) at the hi tide last thursday were the perfect ending after apps at osha, too crowded but still yummy cocktails at rye and tasty byob indian food somewhere right down the block.  I do always love the tloin dive bar feel, from the interesting decor and aromas down to the feeling you really shouldn't touch anything at all or drink out of any of the glasses.  But what really made the night special was our bartender g1 (I'm sure that's not how you spell her name but thats how she explained the pronunciation... Like a g6!).  She was cute and bubbly.  And when she learned it was my birthday poured me a delicious shot and also gave me a half dozen of the most beautifully perfect roses I have ever seen in my whole life!!  Thank you g1 for making my birthday special!!!
author: Bethany N.

description:
Well, I guess it's a convenient location to meet up, and it has a good pool table... beyond that this place didn't have a lot of appeal for me.  The seats and the bar are held together with duct tape, The tables are tiny, shaky and reminded me of play-house furniture.  The place smells of urine, and it's got a strong breeze from outside keeping it pretty cold inside.  I did like the skeezy topless painting over the bar, the only thing that could have made it better is if it were painted on black velvet...
 My friend ordered an Absolute Citron and Soda and had to tell the woman taking our order what was in it "no, it's the bottle with the yellow writing",  "oh, Absolutely" the bartender said with a vacant smile... 
He wound up with a weak vodka tonic...
author: Alexis V.

description:
Smoke friendly dive bar.  Signature art piece behind the bar, clearly purchased from a nearby high end art gallery.  Juke box whose collection probably hasn't been updated since 1991.

Serious drinkers and smokers only please.
author: JBO ..

description:
LOVE!!  This is it, people.  Cheap drinks, pool, stuffing bursting out of seat cushions, shady old men.  Hey, is it my fifth birthday party again??

I will be here, like, every day.
author: Amy M.

description:
I make it a point to stop in at the High Tide every time I'm in town.

The bartenders dress far too skimpily for their age.  The sleaze factor here is high.  Oddly, there's always someone here dressed to the hilt, in party dresses and Prada.  

Also, foul foul foul bathrooms. A jukebox that plays shit and more shit. Overpriced drinks.   Tons of smoke.  

And somehow, I keep coming back.
author: Anthony R.

description: Wasted heading to the hotel .  Need another drink in the tenderloin.. Awesome juke box... Getting my afterhour drink on and throwing salt water taffy around like it's free.  Juke box is great.
author: Robert F.

description:
Best Tenderloin dive bar. Period. Great crazy mixed up jukebox. No pretentious overdone decor. Hot Korean bartenders. Pool table. Cool lamps. Booths. 

Always starts slow and is jammed by the end of the night. The kids from the language school on Sutter always seem to end up here after class- probably because Who's Your Daddy closed. Hear many different languages spoken.

Hungry? Order take out from the most excellent Vietnamese restaurant (Kim Thanh ) across the street and eat at the bar. Try the salted crab. Live shrimp in tanks in the window. 

Best of all- I can walk home! Uphill! 

Check it out.
author: stephan k.

description:
I've lived down the street from here for two years and had never been until a few weeks ago. I was excited, thinking that I had found a new place to catch a cheap drink. But to my extreme disappointment, I found the drinks to be expensive and weak. I'm sorry, but $6 for a tiny cocktail without the slightest trace of booze is ridiculous. And the woman behind the bar was rude and pushy.

Two stars for the jukebox, the only thing that redeemed the experience.
author: Kirsten G.

description:
This place is a bar.  It has a pool table.  It has a juke box.  There really isn't anymore to it.

The bartender was friendly, even when we interrupted her electronic card game.

High Tide is good if you want to chill with friends and have a beer, but it doesn't stand out as unique in the Tenderloin.  Some of the gay dive bars have more grit and flair than this place.
author: Sean O.

description: Dive all the way! The floors are slanted but you can shoot some pool & have a beer without changing into your evening duds. Watch out for what comes out of the mens restroom.
author: Kimberly S.

description: An ultimate dive bar experience. Random photos and paintings on the wall. Stanky as hell bathrooms. Plus points for a jukebox. Very chill, eclectic crowd and within walking distance of pizza joints for the munchies.
author: Thomas L.

description:
OK, I like dive bars. Hell, I love dive bars but here's the thing. They smoke in Hi Tide. Like, full on smoking is happening in here.  At this point you're either going, "ooo don't want to go there" or "frak yeah, it's about time there's somewhere I can light up indoors!"  Call me a snob but I really don't want to hang out in a place where I have to bug bomb my jacket the next day. Never minded smokers, I just can't stand smelling sooty later.

If you're looking for a good dive where you can smoke and be free, check it out but if you're like me, I'd probably avoid it.
author: Andy A.

description:
I don't know why I don't come here more. Well, actually, I do...I'm blessed to live in a neighborhood where there are at least two more fantastic dive (or dive-y) joints closer to my estate.

Really, though, the Hi-Tide Lounge is just perfect: It's sleazy, you can smoke in there, the drinks are cheap, it's close (for me, at least) etc. That's how I like it.
author: Derek R.

description: Cheap and stiff drinks, popcorn, and Britney on the jukebox.  Do you need anything else?
author: Nancy R.

description:
I had my own litlle TL pub crawl and this bar was one of my stops while waiting for my friend to finish getting her haircut. Being a lover of dive bars (I used to work in one) I had to stop in to see what the crowd was like. I stepped into the Hi-Tide and the place was empty except for the bartender and older gentlemen toward the opposite end of the bar. Granted it was 2pm on a Tuesday but I knew why I was there, to drink!!
Here is my Dive Tip #1 If you have never been to a dive bar before, always order bottled beer, preferably one that is popular with the regulars. I do this for a couple of reasons: the glass is always clean, you know what you are drinking (not always the case) and the beer should be fresh (er) if the regulars drink it.
Since there was only 1 regular drinking a clear drink (probably vokda/gin and tonic) I couldn't use my usual process of elimination. So in this case I go with the local beer, why? you may ask, because local beers in tourist locations tend to be ordered more often than national brands (I know I do it on vacation). So I went with Anchor Steam. I had a bottle of Anchor here and moved on to the next bar.
author: D J.

description:
I hadn't been back to the old joint for a few months due to some problems I was having with my hershey squirts.   I would eat something and then blammo, my shorts would be full of muds and worms.  It was something.  
Well the Dr. finally found me some medicine to hold the avalanche inside me tubes and I decided to go out on a bender.  I hit the high tide with 100 dollars and left with a light buzz and no money.  Did I have fun?  Yep.  Did I use the potty?  Yep.  Did I throw up in their trash can?  Yep.  Did I piss on the floor?  Yep.  Did I get a lil' sumpin sumpin in the back room?  Yep.  Was it a girl?  I sure as hell hope so.  
If you like watered down drinks, crappy service, decent music, and a lot of fun, try the High Tide.  If you don't, still try the high tide.  Once you get past the stale piss smell, I think you'll love it.
author: TJ R.

description: I actually got lost a couple of times in this bar. Either the hallways leading to the bathroom were absolutely labyrinthine, or I was just that wasted.
author: Daniel W.

description: Just your regular dive bar, nothing special besides the convenience of being close to empty on a Saturday night. We were looking for something low key after prowling around town all day long enjoying beers, gelato and cannoli so it fit the bill.
author: Giovanni S.

description: My boyfriend lives in the Tenderloin and took me here when I needed to use the facilities after heavy drinking elsewhere.  We sat down at the bar, and I asked the Asian bartender lady for a glass of water.  She told me she would not serve me unless I ordered alcohol.  I didn't want more alcohol, I wanted water.  So my boyfriend pacified her by ordering a beer and a shot of tequila while I headed to the bathroom.  The ladies bathroom was unoccupied, but the door was stuck.  So two nice Latino men told me I could use the men's room.  Of course, the door didn't lock, but I was undeterred because I really needed to go.  I went into the only stall and, as I was peeing, a man STUCK HIS HEAD UNDER THE STALL DOOR to cop an eyeful of my ladyparts.  When I came out and told the bartender about this, she yelled at me for not using the ladies room  - with the non-functioning door.  No reason to go here unless you like pervy entertainment, in which case my experience was 4 stars.
author: H. A.

description: Puh-leez.  If you don't know how to make a goddamn manhattan, why are you working behind the bar?  I can only imagine that the job interview for the barkeep position went:  "Do you know how to make classic cocktails?"  "No."  "Do you know how to look cute and be flirty?" "Yes."  "You're hired!"  Because, really, the bartendress did not know how to make a manhattan, but she sure had the guys at the bar eating out of her hand.  It's a good thing the guys were beer drinkers and she only had to open bottles.  I don't expect the antics of "Cocktail" or "Coyote Ugly" but I DO expect bartenders to be able to make basic cocktails.  Add a mix of predictable hits *yawn* of the 80s and 90s played waaay too loud, and you have the recipe for a bar we decided we'll never patronize again.
author: maiko h.

description:
Well you might have read some of my other reviews by now, I am sorta prolific and often sometimes hilarious. Maybe you are one of my 4 fans. Yeah that's right I have 4! 
Well if so you know I am a drunk, so it will not surprise you that last night I got drunk and decided since my beloved had never been to the high tide that we needed to stop there on our stumble home for one last drink.
